div.head: Model Comparisons Bayesian Analysis
div.p: BGT models: Iterative strategic reasoning Level-0 agents choose actions non-strategically.
In this work (and most others), uniformly at random Level-1 agents reason about level-0 agents.
Level-2 agents reason about level-1 agents. There's a probability distribution over levels.
Higher-level agents are "smarter"; scarcer
Predicting the distribution of play: weighted sum of the distributions for each level.

div.p: Lk model [Costa-Gomes et al. 2001] parameters: (α 1 , α 2 , 1 , 2 ) Each agent has one of 3 levels: level-0, level-1, or level-2.
div.formula: Distribution of level [2, 1, 0] agents is [α 2 , α 1 , (1 − α 1 − α 2 )]
div.p: Each level-k agent makes a "mistake" with prob k , or best responds to level-(k − 1) opponent with prob 1 − k .

Level-k agents believe all opponents are level-(k − 1). Level-k agents aren't aware that level-(k − 1) agents will make "mistakes". An agent of level m best responds to the truncated, true distribution of levels from 0 to m − 1.

div.head: Posterior distributions
div.p: A posterior distribution gives the probability of each possible combination of parameter values, given the data, e.g.:
Maximum likelihood only tells us the most likely parameter setting, given the data.
The posterior distribution over parameter settings describes the relative probability of all possible parameter settings.
Individual parameters can be analyzed by inspecting the marginal posterior distribution.

Parameters for QLk are counterintuitive, hard to identify. Using CH beliefs and a single precision for all agents yields more identifiable parameter values, superior predictive performance.
